author: sky.cactus
content: Keep in mind that the goal is people can run on *consumer hardware*, not *dedicated servers*.

author: sky.cactus
content: Just because someone has 10MBps and a 500GB hard drive doesn't mean they can run 10MBps *constantly all month* and fill 400GB of that drive with nothing but Ethereum.

author: sky.cactus
content: Their computer is likely used for watching Netflix, playing games, storing home videos/photos, etc.

author: sky.cactus
content: The real argument here seems to be that some people believe it is acceptable for Ethereum to only work on dedicated hardware/networks, while others believe that Ethereum should work on personal computers in a traditional home environment.

author: sky.cactus
content: Also, I currently live in a country on the lower end of that speedtest list and I very much question those results...

author: sky.cactus
content: It claims my country gets on the order of 25MBps for mobile broadband and I can say with a great deal of confidence that you won't get that in the vast majority of this country.  You *might* get it in the richest part of the biggest city, but beyond that you are more likely to get 1MBps and it isn't stable.

author: sky.cactus
content: Similar for their fixed bandwidth numbers.  You can get them with a business line, and while they are advertised for consumer connections the connection is very unreliable.

author: sky.cactus
content: Also, keep in mind that many people have monthly bandwidth caps and that is ultimately the limiting factor.   3.3Mbps continuous for a month comes out to 1TB / month if my math is right.  So if you have a 50MBps connection with a 1TB / month cap it doesn't matter, you are still *effectively* capped at 3.3Mbps when it comes to a continuous data stream like Ethereum.

author: sky.cactus
content: And again, this assumes you don't do *anything else* with your internet like watching porn or whatever.

author: sky.cactus
content:
If people really want gas prices to go down I think the right solution is to support/fund/work on:
* layer 2 development
* stateless development
* TG pruning
* DB layout changes in other clients (after TG proves out pruning)

author: jgm
content: I'd rather frame the debate in terms of two positives, rather than a positive and a negative.  Seems we can either have Ethereum with higher decentralisation (lower hardware requirements) or with better user experience  (increased gas limit).  Both have benefits, and it's a question of weighing one against the other.  And it is, of course, a non-linear relationship: it _may_ be possible to increase the gas limit while not significantly impacting decentralisation _up to a point_.  Answers to questions like "if there are more nodes in total, can each node have fewer peers (up to a limit, of course) without harming either the node or the network?"
